name: Organization Context Ontology Glossary
description: Comprehensive glossary of terms defined in the Organization Context Ontology

terms.definition: Rich context container for an organization that links to all contextual sub-entities including products, brands, competitors, market segments, and maturity levels
terms.mappingRationale: Composite context object specific to platform architecture - no schema.org equivalent
terms.example: ctx:foot-scientific
terms.notes: Primary entry point for agent context about an organization

terms.definition: A product or service offered by the organization, with category, segment, and optional value proposition reference
terms.mappingRationale: Direct alignment with schema.org Product type
terms.example: Custom Orthotics - Medical Device product from Foot Scientific
terms.notes: Value proposition details live in VSOM ontology, not here

terms.definition: A brand owned by the organization, which may have its own value proposition
terms.mappingRationale: Direct alignment with schema.org Brand type
terms.example: Foot Scientific brand
terms.notes: Brand-level value propositions are more strategic than product-level

terms.definition: Structured view of organization's product/service offerings including type classification and segment breakdown
terms.mappingRationale: Aggregate portfolio concept not directly in schema.org
terms.constraints: portfolioType must be one of: single_product, multi_product, ecommerce, service, hybrid
terms.example: E-commerce portfolio with 500 products across 5 segments
terms.notes: Helps determine complexity of value proposition modeling

terms.definition: Competitive environment context including named competitors, Porter forces, and market trends
terms.mappingRationale: Strategic analysis concept not in schema.org
terms.example: Foot Scientific competitive landscape with Superfeet and Powerstep as primary competitors
terms.notes: Used for AI citation tracking and competitive monitoring

terms.definition: Named competitor organization with analysis including type, priority, strengths, weaknesses, and tracking preferences
terms.mappingRationale: Competitive analysis entity specific to platform functionality
terms.constraints: Must reference valid Organization entity, priority 1-5
terms.example: Superfeet - direct competitor, priority 1, tracked for citations and rankings
terms.notes: Competitors can exist at platform, client, and client's client levels

terms.definition: Porter-style competitive force affecting the market (threat of entry, substitutes, buyer power, supplier power, rivalry)
terms.mappingRationale: Strategic framework concept from Porter's Five Forces
terms.constraints: forceType must be valid Porter force, intensity: low/medium/high
terms.example: Threat of substitutes - high intensity in orthotics market
terms.notes: Helps understand market dynamics for strategic positioning

terms.definition: Macro trend affecting the market including type (regulatory, technological, economic, social, environmental, political) and impact assessment
terms.mappingRationale: Strategic planning concept not directly in schema.org
terms.constraints: trendType must be valid category, impact: positive/negative/neutral/uncertain
terms.example: AI-powered foot scanning - technological trend with positive impact
terms.notes: Timeframe helps prioritize response urgency

terms.definition: Market segments, geography, and localization context for the organization
terms.mappingRationale: Composite market context not directly in schema.org
terms.example: US market focus with podiatry and retail segments
terms.notes: Includes localization settings (currency, geography, languages)

terms.definition: Target market segment defined by industry, geography, size, and priority level
terms.mappingRationale: Market segmentation concept specific to B2B analysis
terms.example: Podiatry Clinics - primary segment in Healthcare industry
terms.notes: Used for campaign targeting and content strategy

terms.definition: High-level customer need identifier including type (job-to-be-done, pain point, value driver, unmet need) and priority
terms.mappingRationale: Jobs-to-be-done framework concept
terms.constraints: Detailed pains/gains live in Value Proposition Ontology
terms.example: Chronic foot pain affecting daily activities - critical pain point
terms.notes: High-level only here - details in VSOM ontology

terms.definition: Organization maturity assessment across multiple dimensions including size, value, marketing, technology, complexity, and AI readiness
terms.mappingRationale: Maturity model concept specific to platform assessment
terms.example: SME with marketing maturity 2, technology maturity 3
terms.notes: Informs service recommendations and feature enablement

terms.definition: Reference to a value proposition defined in the VSOM ontology - not the actual value proposition details
terms.mappingRationale: Reference pattern - actual definition in separate ontology
terms.example: vp:foot-scientific-brand
terms.notes: Separation allows value propositions to be managed independently

terms.definition: Size maturity dimension including level (1-5), headcount, revenue, and revenue currency
terms.mappingRationale: Composite maturity assessment object
terms.example: Level 2, 75 employees, $8M USD revenue
terms.notes: Used for pricing tier determination

terms.definition: Marketing capability maturity including level (1-5), marketing director presence, team size, and functional roles
terms.mappingRationale: Marketing capability assessment specific to platform
terms.constraints: level: 1-5, functionalRoles from standard marketing role list
terms.example: Level 2, no marketing director, 2 team members, Content and Social roles
terms.notes: Informs service recommendations and self-service vs managed approach

terms.definition: AI-specific maturity assessment including maturity level, tools in use, AI visibility awareness, and current strategy
terms.mappingRationale: BAIV-specific assessment dimension
terms.example: Exploring level, using ChatGPT for content, medium AI visibility awareness
terms.notes: Key input for discovery audit and gap analysis

terms.definition: Boolean flag indicating whether to track AI platform citations for a competitor
terms.mappingRationale: BAIV-specific tracking preference
terms.example: true - track how often Superfeet is cited by ChatGPT, Claude, etc.
terms.notes: Core BAIV functionality for competitive AI visibility monitoring

terms.definition: Boolean flag indicating whether to track search rankings for a competitor
terms.mappingRationale: SEO monitoring preference
terms.example: true - track Superfeet's Google rankings for target keywords
terms.notes: Traditional SEO monitoring alongside AI visibility

terms.definition: Localization settings including base currency, base geography, and supported languages
terms.mappingRationale: Composite localization object for multi-market support
terms.example: USD currency, United States geography, en-US language
terms.notes: Important for multi-national clients and agencies

terms.definition: Product segment within a portfolio - used for e-commerce and multi-product businesses instead of individual product value propositions
terms.mappingRationale: Product grouping concept for simplified value proposition modeling
terms.constraints: Free text, should align with business terminology
terms.example: Work Shoes segment for Shoe Carnival
terms.notes: Value propositions typically defined at segment level, not individual product level
